Knowledge Point: In Rapa Nui, different strategies are used to combine clauses, depending on the type of clause. Some constructions have a conjunction, others have a preverbal subordinating \is{Conjunction}marker, others yet are unmarked.\footnote{\label{fn:503}The latter can be recognised as subordinate clauses by the use of the negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} (see \REF{ex:11.210} on p.~\pageref{ex:11.210}), and by the use of aspectual marker (only i, e or ka; the verb is always followed by a postverbal demonstrative).} Conjunctions only occur in certain types of adverbial clauses and will be discussed in the appropriate subsections of \sectref{sec:11.6}. Preverbal markers cut through the distinction between types of subordinate clauses, therefore they are discussed separately in \sectref{sec:11.5}.
Content 1: \gll \obI \textbf{ta\ꞌe} kore era tu\ꞌu tokerau era\,\cb he mana\ꞌu mo haka tītika i te vaka ki Tahiti. | \gls {\db}PFV CONNEG lack DIST POSS.2SG.O wind DIST NTR think for CAUS straight ACC ART boat to Tahiti | \glt ‘When the wind did not die down, they decided to steer the boat to Tahiti.’

Knowledge Point: Old Rapa Nui did not have a coordinating conjunction\is{Conjunction}. Both phrases and clauses were linked by simple juxtaposition (i.e. asyndetic coordination, see \citealt[7]{Haspelmath2007}). \REF{ex:11.1} shows juxtaposed clauses, while \REF{ex:11.2} contains a string of juxtaposed noun phrases.
Content 1: \gll He oho a te ara, he tike\ꞌa te kohe; he rei hai va\ꞌe, he hati te kohe... | \gls NTR go by ART road NTR see ART kohe NTR step INS foot NTR break ART kohe | \glt ‘He went along the road, he saw a kohe plant; he stepped on it, the kohe broke...’
Content 2: \gll He māmate te taŋata, te vi\ꞌe, te poki, te korohu\ꞌa. | \gls NTR PL:die ART man ART woman ART child ART old_man | \glt ‘Men, women, children, old people died.’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes the adverbs \textit{tako{\ꞌ}a}\is{tako{\ꞌ}a ‘also’} and hoki\is{hoki ‘also’} ‘also’ (\sectref{sec:4.5.3.2}–\ref{sec:4.5.3.3}) are used to link clauses or phrases. In \REF{ex:11.3}, two clauses with similar information about different participants are linked with \textit{tako{\ꞌ}a}. In \REF{ex:11.4}, the last item in a list of noun phrases is marked with hoki. The latter happens only in older texts.
Content 1: \gll He to\ꞌo Hereveri i tō\ꞌona o te tīta\ꞌa henua, he to\ꞌo \textbf{tako\ꞌa} Te Roŋo i tō\ꞌona o te tīta\ꞌa. | \gls NTR take Hereveri ACC POSS.3SG.O of ART terrain land NTR take also Te Rongo ACC POSS.3SG.O of ART terrain | \glt ‘Hereveri took his piece of land; Te Rongo took his piece of land as well.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI te tapa te matu\ꞌa, a koro, a nua, te uka riva, te repa riva \textbf{hoki}. | \gls at ART side ART parents PROP Dad PROP Mum PROP girl good PROP young_man good also | \glt ‘To the side are the parents, the fathers, the mothers, the pretty girls, also the handsome boys.’

Knowledge Point: When two clauses are both under the scope of a single initial constituent, they are usually juxtaposed without conjunction\is{Conjunction} and without repetition of the initial constituent. Examples are \textit{{\ꞌ}o ira} ‘therefore’ in \REF{ex:11.13} and the interrogative phrase in \REF{ex:11.14}. As \REF{ex:11.14} also shows, verb phrase particles – both the aspectual and the negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} – are repeated in the second clause.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌE \textbf{\ꞌo} \textbf{ira} a mātou i tu\ꞌu mai nei i \ꞌauario nei i te mōai nei. | \gls and because_of ANA PROP 1PL.EXCL PFV arrive hither PROX PFV guard PROX ACC ART statue PROX | \glt ‘And therefore we have come and put this statue under guard.’
Content 2: \gll ¿\textbf{He} \textbf{aha} rā ia kōrua \textbf{i} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} oho mai ai \textbf{i} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} hā\ꞌaki mai ai...? | \gls PRED what INTENS then 2PL PFV CONNEG go hither PVP PFV CONNEG inform hither PVP | \glt ‘Why didn’t you come and tell me...?’
Content 3: \gll ¿\textbf{He} \textbf{aha} rā ia kōrua \textbf{i} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} oho mai ai \textbf{i} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} hā\ꞌaki mai ai...? | \gls PRED what INTENS then 2PL PFV CONNEG go hither PVP PFV CONNEG inform hither PVP | \glt ‘Why didn’t you come and tell me...?’

Knowledge Point: When two noun phrases are coordinated in modern Rapa Nui, they are usually linked with \textit{{\ꞌ}e}. When the list is longer than two as in \REF{ex:11.16}, \textit{{\ꞌ}e} occurs only before the last item; the other items are juxtaposed:
Content 1: \gll He marere he oho rō \ꞌai te pipihoreko, te manavai \textbf{\ꞌe} te hare moa. | \gls NTR scatter NTR go EMPH SUBS ART cairn ART rock_garden and ART house chicken | \glt ‘The rock piles, the rock gardens and the chicken houses gradually fell apart.’

Knowledge Point: When noun phrases marked with prepositions are coordinated, the preposition is repeated, including the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i; the last item may be preceded by \textit{{\ꞌ}e} as in (\ref{ex:11.17}–\ref{ex:11.18}), but juxtaposition is also common, as in (\ref{ex:11.19}–\ref{ex:11.20}):
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI roto i te piha nei a kōrua ka hāpī ena \textbf{i} te tai\ꞌo \textbf{\ꞌe} \textbf{i} te pāpa\ꞌi. | \gls at inside at ART room PROX PROP 2PL CNTG learn MED ACC ART read and ACC ART write | \glt ‘In this (class)room you will learn to read and to write.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI roto i te māhatu \textbf{o} tā\ꞌana vi\ꞌe \textbf{\ꞌe} \textbf{o} tā\ꞌana ŋā poki... | \gls at inside at ART heart of POSS.3SG.A woman and of POSS.3SG.A PL child | \glt ‘In the heart of his wife and of his children...’
Content 3: \gll Kā ŋā poki he ma\ꞌu \textbf{i} te keke, \textbf{i} te haraoa, \textbf{i} te me\ꞌe. | \gls every PL child NTR carry ACC ART cake ACC ART bread ACC ART thing | \glt ‘All the children carried cakes, bread and (other) things.’
Content 4: \gll He hiro i te hau mo hī \textbf{o} te kahi \textbf{o} te ika. | \gls NTR braid ACC ART line for to_fish of ART tuna of ART fish | \glt ‘He braided lines for fishing tuna (and) (other) fish.’

Knowledge Point: Despite its frequent use in everyday speech, pero is perceived as an intrusion, as witnessed by the fact that it is little used in the written texts in the corpus. In the Bible translation, it is not used at all. As \REF{ex:11.8} above shows, \textit{{\ꞌ}e} is also used in situations where other languages would have an adversative conjunction.
Content 1: \gll Te \ꞌāriŋa he taŋata mau ena, \textbf{\ꞌe} te hakari he kavakava. | \gls ART face PRED person really MED and ART body NTR rib | \glt ‘Their faces were like (normal) people, but their bodies were ribs.’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui, disjunction is expressed by \textit{{\ꞌ}o} ‘or’\is{o ‘or’@{\ꞌ}o ‘or’|(},\footnote{\label{fn:505}This particle should not be confused with preverbal \textit{{\ꞌ}o} ‘lest’ (\sectref{sec:11.5.4}), or with the preposition \textit{{\ꞌ}o} ‘because of’ (\sectref{sec:4.7.2.2}).} a conjunction borrowed from \ili{Spanish} o. \textit{{\ꞌ}O} may connect clauses as in (\ref{ex:11.23}–\ref{ex:11.24}) or phrases as in \REF{ex:11.25}:
Content 1: \gll Te ŋā kai \ꞌāpī ra\ꞌe era ana momore, ana pa\ꞌo, \textbf{\ꞌo} ana keri, e ma\ꞌu to te hare pure \ꞌi ra\ꞌe. | \gls NTR PL food new first DIST IRR RED:cut IRR chop or IRR dig IPFV carry ART:of ART house pray at first | \glt ‘The first new food which would be picked, cut or dug up, had to be taken to the church first.’
Content 2: \gll ...he oho \textbf{\ꞌo} he hāpī \textbf{\ꞌo} he e\ꞌa he ha\ꞌere \textbf{\ꞌo} he oho ki kampō. | \gls ~~~NTR go or NTR learn or NTR go_out NTR walk or NTR go to countryside | \glt ‘(When his work was finished,) he would go or study or go out for a walk or go to the countryside.’
Content 3: \gll He \ꞌaiua i te aŋa ki a nua \textbf{\ꞌo} ki a koro. | \gls NTR help ACC ART work to PROP Mum or to PROP Dad | \glt ‘They help Mum or Dad with the work.’

Knowledge Point: Unlike \textit{{\ꞌ}e} ‘and’, \textit{{\ꞌ}o} may also connect nouns; in that case, the parts on either side of \textit{{\ꞌ}o} are not complete noun phrases. In the following examples, \textit{{\ꞌ}o} is directly followed by the second noun; prenominal elements, such as determiners and the plural marker ŋā in \REF{ex:11.26}, precede the first noun, while the postnominal demonstrative era follows the second noun:
Content 1: \gll ...\ꞌi \obte ŋā tāpati \textbf{\ꞌo} \ꞌāva\ꞌe era\,\cb e noho era \ꞌi tahatai. | \gls ~~~at {\db}ART PL week or month DIST IPFV stay DIST at coast | \glt ‘...in the weeks or months they stay on the coast.’

Knowledge Point: While independent clauses may be separated from the matrix clause by markers such as pē nei ē ‘like this, as follows’ (see e.g. \REF{ex:11.65} below), this is not possible in asyndetically coordinated clauses.
Content 1: \gll Ko \ꞌite rivariva \ꞌā e koe pē nei ē: ko haŋa \ꞌā a ia mo oho mo hāpī. | \gls PRF know good:RED CONT AG 2SG like PROX thus PRF want CONT PROP 3SG for go for study | \glt ‘You know very well that she wants to go and study.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Verb!perception}The ko{}-marked complement is often a stative verb or a temporal noun like pō ‘night’; the perfect aspect\is{Aspect!perfect} expresses that this state has come about in some way, without specifying how. In \REF{ex:11.35} it is night because it has become night, and the ship is far from Rapa Nui because it has been moving further and further away.
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi atu \textbf{ko} \textbf{pō} \textbf{\ꞌā}, \ꞌe \textbf{ko} \textbf{roaroa} \textbf{\ꞌana} te pahī mai Rapa Nui. | \gls NTR look away PRF night CONT and PRF distant:RED CONT ART ship from Rapa Nui | \glt ‘She saw that it was night, and that the ship was far from Rapa Nui.’

Knowledge Point: Often a perception verb is followed first by an object NP expressing the person or thing which is perceived, then a clause specifying what happens to this referent (cf. \ili{English} ‘he saw someone coming’). The object NP in this construction may be marked in several ways: with the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i as in (\ref{ex:11.38}–\ref{ex:11.39}), but also with the topic marker ko\is{ko (prominence marker)} as in (\ref{ex:11.40}–\ref{ex:11.41}) (\sectref{sec:8.6.4.5}). The verb in the complement clause is often marked with ka\is{ka (aspect marker)}.
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi \textbf{i} tū kahu era ō\ꞌona ko momore tahi \ꞌā.\textup{} | \gls NTR look ACC DEM clothes DIST POSS.3SG.O PRF RED:cut all CONT | \glt ‘He saw that those clothes of his were all torn.’
Content 2: \gll He take\ꞌa \textbf{i} a Hoto Vari ka pū mai. | \gls NTR see ACC PROP Hoto Vari CNTG approach hither | \glt ‘He saw Hoto Vari approaching.’
Content 3: \gll E ha\ꞌuru nō \ꞌā a Eva he hakaroŋo atu \textbf{ko} te re\ꞌo ka raŋi... | \gls IPFV sleep just CONT PROP Eva NTR listen away PROM ART voice CNTG call | \glt ‘When Eva was sleeping, she heard a voice calling...’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌĪ ka u\ꞌi mai nei \textbf{ko} te kio\ꞌe e rua ka o\ꞌo ka oho atu. | \gls IMM CNTG see hither PROX PROM ART rat NUM two CNTG enter CNTG go away | \glt ‘There he sees two rats making their way in (lit. entering going).’

Knowledge Point: How should these constructions be analysed? At first sight, the complement clause in (\ref{ex:11.38}–\ref{ex:11.41}) can be considered as a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} to the object. One argument against this is the function of the aspect marker\is{Aspect marker}: whereas relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} marked with ka usually express an event posterior\is{Posteriority} to that in the surrounding clause(s) (\sectref{sec:11.4.3}), in these examples the ka{}-marked clauses express an event \is{Simultaneity}simultaneous to the perception event of the matrix clause. Moreover, as \REF{ex:11.39} shows, the clause may follow a proper noun, even though proper nouns\is{Noun!proper} normally do not take relative clauses\is{Clause!relative}.
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi \textbf{i} tū kahu era ō\ꞌona ko momore tahi \ꞌā.\textup{} | \gls NTR look ACC DEM clothes DIST POSS.3SG.O PRF RED:cut all CONT | \glt ‘He saw that those clothes of his were all torn.’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌĪ ka u\ꞌi mai nei \textbf{ko} te kio\ꞌe e rua ka o\ꞌo ka oho atu. | \gls IMM CNTG see hither PROX PROM ART rat NUM two CNTG enter CNTG go away | \glt ‘There he sees two rats making their way in (lit. entering going).’
Content 3: \gll He take\ꞌa \textbf{i} a Hoto Vari ka pū mai. | \gls NTR see ACC PROP Hoto Vari CNTG approach hither | \glt ‘He saw Hoto Vari approaching.’

Knowledge Point: Therefore it seems more plausible to consider the nominal complement and the complement clause as a single constituent. The fact that the noun phrase can be marked with ko\is{ko (prominence marker)} (which is the default case marker in the absence of other markers) is an argument for this analysis. Constructions (\ref{ex:11.38}–\ref{ex:11.39}) suggest that this noun phrase can be raised to the object position of the matrix verb.
Content 1: \gll He u\ꞌi \textbf{i} tū kahu era ō\ꞌona ko momore tahi \ꞌā.\textup{} | \gls NTR look ACC DEM clothes DIST POSS.3SG.O PRF RED:cut all CONT | \glt ‘He saw that those clothes of his were all torn.’
Content 2: \gll He take\ꞌa \textbf{i} a Hoto Vari ka pū mai. | \gls NTR see ACC PROP Hoto Vari CNTG approach hither | \glt ‘He saw Hoto Vari approaching.’

Knowledge Point: \textit{Ha{\ꞌ}amata} ‘begin’ is usually followed by a clause expressing the event which begins. In most cases this clause is juxtaposed, with the same verb marking as \textit{\mbox{ha{\ꞌ}amata}}. Thus, both verbs may be marked with neutral he as in \REF{ex:11.42}, perfective i as in \REF{ex:11.43}, or perfect \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} as in \REF{ex:11.44}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} ha\ꞌamata te perete\ꞌi \textbf{he} hīmene. | \gls NTR begin ART cricket NTR sing | \glt ‘The cricket started to sing.’
Content 2: \gll Pē ira \textbf{i} ha\ꞌamata ai te tūrita \textbf{i} tu\ꞌu mai ai ki nei. | \gls like ANA PFV begin PVP ART tourist PFV arrive hither PVP to PROX | \glt ‘In that way, the tourists started to arrive here.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌI tū hora era \textbf{ko} ha\ꞌamata atu \textbf{\ꞌana} tū \ꞌua era \textbf{ko} hoa \textbf{\ꞌā}. | \gls at DEM time DIST PRF begin away CONT DEM rain DIST PRF throw CONT | \glt ‘At that time the rain had started to fall.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Verb!aspectual verb}This identical marking is not limited to aspect markers\is{Aspect marker}. In \REF{ex:11.45}, both verbs are marked with the negator kai. In \REF{ex:11.46}, \textit{ha{\ꞌ}amata} is the verb of a bare relative clause\is{Clause!relative!bare} (\sectref{sec:11.4.5}), which is characterised by the absence of an aspect marker; the complement verb \textit{tu{\ꞌ}u} is likewise unmarked.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Kai} ha\ꞌamata a au \textbf{kai} pa\ꞌo \ꞌā e tahi miro. | \gls NEG.PFV begin PROP 1SG NEG.PFV chop CONT NUM one tree | \glt ‘I haven’t yet started to chop down a tree.’
Content 2: \gll Hora \textbf{ha\ꞌamata} \textbf{tu\ꞌu} mai era o te pere\ꞌoa \ꞌi nei \ꞌana... | \gls time begin arrive hither DIST of ART car at PROX IDENT | \glt ‘When cars started to arrive here...’

Knowledge Point: As (\ref{ex:11.42}–\ref{ex:11.45}) show, the S/A of the second verb is often placed in the subject\is{Subject!raising} position of the matrix clause. However, it may also be placed after the complement verb:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} ha\ꞌamata te perete\ꞌi \textbf{he} hīmene. | \gls NTR begin ART cricket NTR sing | \glt ‘The cricket started to sing.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Kai} ha\ꞌamata a au \textbf{kai} pa\ꞌo \ꞌā e tahi miro. | \gls NEG.PFV begin PROP 1SG NEG.PFV chop CONT NUM one tree | \glt ‘I haven’t yet started to chop down a tree.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Verb!aspectual verb}A second construction is that in which the complement is expressed as a nominalised\is{Verb!nominalised} verb (i.e. preceded by the determiner te). This complement may have the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i\is{i (accusative marker)} as in \REF{ex:11.48}, but usually this marker is omitted, as in \REF{ex:11.49}:
Content 1: \gll ...i ha\ꞌamata ai \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{amo} i te mā\ꞌea era o te kona ena. | \gls ~~~PFV begin PVP ACC ART clean ACC ART stone DIST of ART place MED | \glt ‘...they started to clear away the stones in that place.’
Content 2: \gll He ha\ꞌamata a Kava \textbf{te} \textbf{māuiui}. | \gls NTR begin PROP Kava ART sick | \glt ‘Kava started to get ill.’

Knowledge Point: Despite the nominalised character of the complement, it still has verbal characteristics: its Patient (\textit{i te mā{\ꞌ}ea era} in \REF{ex:11.48}) is marked with i.
Content 1: \gll ...i ha\ꞌamata ai \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{amo} i te mā\ꞌea era o te kona ena. | \gls ~~~PFV begin PVP ACC ART clean ACC ART stone DIST of ART place MED | \glt ‘...they started to clear away the stones in that place.’

Knowledge Point: The complement verb is nominalised\is{Verb!nominalised}, i.e. marked with the article te. Sometimes it is preceded by the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} i, in other cases i is omitted.\footnote{\label{fn:506}In \ili{Māori}, the complement verb never has the accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)}; \citet{Hooper1984Unusual} argues that the complement verb is the subject of oti.} As the examples show, the subject of the second verb may be placed in the subject position of oti\is{Subject!raising} as in \REF{ex:11.50} and \REF{ex:11.52}, or follow the complement verb as in \REF{ex:11.51} and \REF{ex:11.53}.
Content 1: \gll I oti era tū taŋata era \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{vānaŋa}... | \gls PFV finish DIST DEM person DIST ACC ART speak | \glt ‘When the man had finished speaking...’
Content 2: \gll ...\ꞌo ira kai hini i oti tahi rō ai tū hare era \textbf{te} \textbf{vera}. | \gls ~~~because_of ANA NEG.PFV delay PFV finish all EMPH PVP DEM house DIST ART burn | \glt ‘...therefore it wasn’t long before the house was completely burned.’
Content 3: \gll Ko oti \ꞌā \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{hopu} Kaiŋa i tō\ꞌona rima. | \gls PRF finish CONT ACC ART wash Kainga ACC POSS.3SG.O hand | \glt ‘Kainga had finished washing his hands.’
Content 4: \gll I oti era \textbf{te} \textbf{kī} au, he turu ko au ko te vi\ꞌe. | \gls PFV finish DIST ART say 1SG NTR go_down PROM 1SG PROM ART woman | \glt ‘When I had finished saying this, I went down (to the coast) with my wife.’

Knowledge Point: Oti as a matrix verb with a complement may also be expressed in a serial verb\is{Serial verb} construction. For examples, see (\ref{ex:7.181}–\ref{ex:7.182}) in \sectref{sec:7.7.3}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{I} \textbf{tuha\ꞌa} \textbf{i} \textbf{oti} era e Kaiŋa i tū kai era... | \gls PRF distribute PFV finish DIST AG Kainga ACC DEM food DIST | \glt ‘When Kainga had finished distributing (=completely distributed) the food...’
Content 2: \gll \ꞌI te toru mahana \textbf{ko} \textbf{para} \textbf{ko} \textbf{oti} \ꞌana. | \gls at ART three day PRF ripe PRF finish CONT | \glt ‘On the third day (the bananas) are completely ripe.’

Knowledge Point: in juxtaposition as in \REF{ex:11.55}, with identical marking of both verbs;
Content 1: \gll E hōrou koe \textbf{e} \textbf{turu}. | \gls EXH hurry 2SG EXH go_down | \glt ‘Go down quickly.’

Knowledge Point: as a serial verb\is{Serial verb} as in \REF{ex:11.56}, with repetition of the aspect marker\is{Aspect marker}, but nothing else between the two verbs (\sectref{sec:7.7} on serial verbs);
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira i hōrou \textbf{i} \textbf{oho} mai era \ꞌi tū mahana era. | \gls because_of ANA PFV quick PFV go hither DIST at DEM day DIST | \glt ‘Therefore he went quickly that day.’

Knowledge Point: as a nominalised verb\is{Verb!nominalised}, either with accusative marker\is{i (accusative marker)} as in \REF{ex:11.57}, or without as in \REF{ex:11.58}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira i ta\ꞌe hōrou ai \textbf{i} \textbf{te} \textbf{vara\ꞌa} i te taŋata o ruŋa. | \gls because_of ANA PFV CONNEG quick PVP ACC ART obtain ACC ART person of above | \glt ‘Therefore, they didn’t catch the people on top (of the islet) quickly.’
Content 2: \gll E ko hōrou te ika \textbf{te} \textbf{pū} mo pātia hai pātia ku hape \ꞌā te haha\ꞌu iŋa. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV quick ART fish ART approach for spear INS spear PRF fault CONT ART tie NMLZ | \glt ‘The fish would not come quickly to be speared with a harpoon that had not been tied properly.’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:11.58} shows, the subject of the second verb may be raised to the subject\is{Subject!raising} position of hōrou (in this case, the Patient is raised, showing that the complement clause is passivised\is{Passive}).
Content 1: \gll E ko hōrou te ika \textbf{te} \textbf{pū} mo pātia hai pātia ku hape \ꞌā te haha\ꞌu iŋa. | \gls IPFV NEG.IPFV quick ART fish ART approach for spear INS spear PRF fault CONT ART tie NMLZ | \glt ‘The fish would not come quickly to be speared with a harpoon that had not been tied properly.’

Knowledge Point: The content of knowledge or thought may also be an event. This is expressed by an independent clause, which can be nominal as in \REF{ex:11.61} or verbal as in (\ref{ex:11.62}–\ref{ex:11.63}). As \REF{ex:11.64} shows, the clause may also be a dependent question. In each example, the bracketed part could function as a clause by itself.
Content 1: \gll Ko \textbf{\ꞌite} \ꞌana ho\ꞌi kōrua \obte vārua me\ꞌe mana\,\cb. | \gls PRF know CONT indeed 2PL {\db}ART spirit thing power | \glt ‘You know that spirits are powerful.’
Content 2: \gll He \textbf{aŋiaŋi} e Ataraŋa \obe ko hoki haka\ꞌou tū vi\ꞌe era \ꞌā\ꞌana\,\cb. | \gls NTR certain:RED AG Ataranga {\db}IPFV NEG.IPFV return again DEM women DIST POSS.3SG.A | \glt ‘Ataranga knew for sure that his wife would not return.’
Content 3: \gll He \textbf{mana\ꞌu} rō \ꞌai te taŋata o nei \obko māmate \ꞌā a koā Taparahi\,\cb. | \gls NTR think EMPH SUBS ART person of PROX {\db}PRF PL:die CONT PROP COLL Taparahi | \glt ‘The people here thought that Taparahi and the others had died.’
Content 4: \gll Ko \textbf{\ꞌite} \ꞌana ho\ꞌi kōrua \ob\ꞌi hē a ia\,\cb. | \gls PRF know CONT indeed 2PL {\db}at CQ PROP 3SG | \glt ‘For you know where she is.’

Knowledge Point: When \textit{{\ꞌ}ite}\is{ite ‘to know’@{\ꞌ}ite ‘to know’} ‘to know’ is followed by i te V (i.e. a nominalised verb\is{Verb!nominalised} marked as direct object), it often expresses ability, often a particular skill. Alternatively, it may express a habit or inclination, as in \REF{ex:11.80}.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌIna a au kai \ꞌite i te kai i te \ꞌate. | \gls NEG PROP 1SG NEG.PFV know ACC ART eat ACC ART liver | \glt ‘I don’t eat liver, I’m not used to eating liver.’

Knowledge Point: The subject usually comes after the main verb as in \REF{ex:11.86}; in this respect tiene que is different from other modal verbs\is{Verb!modal}, where the subject follows the modal verb immediately. However, \REF{ex:11.87} shows that the subject can be raised to the subject position of tiene.

Knowledge Point: We can now look once again at the noun phrase hierarchy given in \REF{ex:11.88a} on p.~\pageref{ex:11.88a} above. As \tabref{tab:66} shows, whether or not the situation in Rapa Nui conforms to Keenan & Comrie’s generalisation that every relativising strategy involves a continuous segment of the hierarchy, depends on how the syntactic categories of Rapa Nui are mapped to this hierarchy. Knowledge Point: Possessive-relative constructions occur in other Polynesian languages as well. There has been some discussion on the question whether the possessor\is{Possession} is raised from the subject\is{Subject!raising} position of the relative clause\is{Clause!relative} (e.g. \citealt[367]{Harlow2000}; \citealt[185]{Harlow2007Maori}), or whether it is a genuine noun phrase possessor\is{Possession} which happens to be coreferential to the relative clause subject \citep[116]{Clark1976}. In Rapa Nui the second option is more plausible. First, the possessor\is{Possession} can be in the same positions as in any other noun phrase, which suggests that it is no different from other possessors in the noun phrase. Second, as the examples above show, the form of the possessive construction varies between \is{Possession!o/a distinction}a- and o-possession: a{}-possession in \REF{ex:11.123}, \REF{ex:11.125} and \REF{ex:11.127}, o{}-possession in \REF{ex:11.124} and \REF{ex:11.126}. As a- and o-possession express different semantic relationships between possessor\is{Possession} and possessee (\sectref{sec:6.3.2}), this suggests that there is a direct relation between the possessor\is{Possession} and the head noun, even though the primary function of the possessor\is{Possession} seems to be the expression of the relative clause\is{Clause!relative} subject.\footnote{\label{fn:517}\citet{HerdMacdonald2011} make a similar observation for other Polynesian languages. They propose a structure where there is a relation between the possessor\is{Possession} and the relative construction as a whole. This involves a control relation (not raising) between possessor\is{Possession} and relative clause\is{Clause!relative} subject.} And indeed, in most of these cases the choice between \textit{{\ꞌ}a} and o is governed by the same principles guiding this choice in possessive constructions in general. In \REF{ex:11.127}, where the relation between possessor\is{Possession} and head noun is one between husband and wife, \textit{{\ꞌ}a} is used (\sectref{sec:6.3.3.1.1}). In \REF{ex:11.125}, the use of \textit{{\ꞌ}a} is possibly motivated by the active relationship of the possessee to the head noun ‘work’ (\sectref{sec:6.3.3.2} item 2). In \REF{ex:11.126}, o is used with a temporal noun, again conforming to a general pattern (\sectref{sec:6.3.3.3} item 11). In fact, given the wide range of relationships expressed by possessive constructions in Rapa Nui, all possessive-relatives seem to exhibit some kind of possessive relationship also attested in simple possessive constructions.

Knowledge Point: Another reason to consider era as postnominal rather than postverbal, is that it co-occurs with the demonstrative tū, which is always accompanied by a postnominal de\-mon\-strative\is{Demonstrative!postnominal} (\sectref{sec:4.6.2.1}). When tū co-occurs with era after the verb, this suggests that the verb has been raised.\footnote{\label{fn:519}Relative clause verbs may have a postverbal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postverbal}, even when the head noun also has a demonstrative; see \textit{nu{\ꞌ}u era {\ob}oho era\,{\cb}} in \REF{ex:11.134}. Nevertheless, raised verbs never have a demonstrative of their own: two consecutive demonstratives\is{Demonstrative} never occur (\textit{*nu{\ꞌ}u {\ob}oho\,{\cb} era {\ob}era\,{\cb}}). This can be accounted for by a rule deleting one of two consecutive demonstratives\is{Demonstrative}.} This is illustrated in \REF{ex:11.135} above; the same analysis can be extended to examples such as the following:

Knowledge Point: Examples such as (\ref{ex:11.139}–\ref{ex:11.140}) are quite common. Leaving out the aspectual has the effect of downplaying the action/event character of the relative clause\is{Clause!relative}: what the relative clause\is{Clause!relative} denotes is not so much an event but rather a fact; this fact is part of the referential description in the noun phrase.

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:11.164} shows, ana can be followed by evaluative markers (rō\is{ro (emphatic marker)@rō (emphatic marker)}) and directionals\is{Directional} (mai). It cannot be followed by postverbal demonstratives\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} or the VP{}-final particles \textit{{\ꞌ}ā} and \textit{{\ꞌ}ai}.

Knowledge Point: \paragraph{} Ana is used to express \textsc{intentions}. While the outcome of the intended event is inherently uncertain, the intention itself may be quite firm: \REF{ex:11.165} occurs in a context where two parents have just agreed to call their baby Tahonga; in the quoted sentence, this decision is confirmed.
Content 1: \gll Ko Tahoŋa te \ꞌīŋoa o te tāua poki \textbf{ana} nape. | \gls PROM Tahonga ART name of DEM 1DU.INCL child IRR call | \glt ‘Tahonga is the name we will call our child.’

Knowledge Point: Even without a conditional clause\is{Clause!conditional} construction, the occurrence of the event marked by ana may be contingent on another event: it is the result of, or at least follows upon, an event expressed in an earlier clause: ‘X, only then Y’. In this case – as in \REF{ex:11.93} above – the verb is usually followed by iho ‘just then’.

Knowledge Point: In the second person, deontic\is{Deontic mode} ana is similar in function to imperative\is{Imperative} ka and exhortative\is{Exhortative} e. While the latter two are only used with clause-initial verbs, ana is especially used when the verb phrase is non-initial. In \REF{ex:11.176}, initial e alternates with non-initial ana:

Knowledge Point: \paragraph{} Ana may also mark clauses which express a \textsc{general practice}, something which \textbf{is} normally/usually done in a given situation. This use is found especially in procedural contexts, where the speaker describes how certain things are normally done or should be done. In Rapa Nui, procedures are generally expressed by strings of he{}-clauses, with occasional imperatives\is{Imperative} (see \REF{ex:7.5} on p.~\pageref{ex:7.5}). But ana may be used as well, especially when the verb is non-initial.

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the apodosis is usually marked with an aspectual, i.e. in the realis\is{Realis} mood. Alternatively, the apodosis may also be marked with ana (cf. \REF{ex:11.168} above). This can lead to a situation in which both the conditional clause\is{Clause!conditional} and the apodosis are marked with ana:

Knowledge Point: In other cases, the question is not whether the event in the subordinate clause happens, but when: the event is expected to happen or has already happened, and the same is true for the main clause event dependent on it. However, ana signals that the clause is still irrealis\is{Irrealis} in some way. It may indicate an event which takes or took place habitually (see the discussion about \REF{ex:11.178} above), or an event which is expected (with more or less certainty) to take place in the future. Ana is not used with events which have taken place at a definite moment in the past.

Content 3: \gll O te hānau \ꞌe\ꞌepe i keri ai i te rua... mo pae o te hānau momoko, \textbf{ki} noho e hānau \ꞌe\ꞌepe nō. | \gls of ART race corpulent PFV dig PVP ACC ART hole for finished of ART race slender to stay AG race corpulent just | \glt ‘The ‘corpulent race’ dug a hole... to exterminate the ‘slender race’, so the ‘corpulent race’ would be the only ones (left).’

Knowledge Point: A peculiarity of ki{}-clauses with purpose sense, is that the verb is often followed by ai, the postverbal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} which otherwise only occurs after i (\sectref{sec:7.6.5}). This is illustrated in \REF{ex:11.188} and \REF{ex:11.190} above.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌĪ e pohe atu ena mo \ꞌata noho mai \textbf{ki} \ꞌata keukeu ai tētahi aŋa. | \gls IMM IPFV desire away MED for more stay hither to more labour:RED PVP other work | \glt ‘I would like him to stay here a bit more, in order to get other projects done.’
Content 2: \gll ¿He aha te me\ꞌe i me\ꞌe e ia \textbf{ki} aŋiaŋi ai e tātou ko koa \ꞌā? | \gls ~PRED thing ART thing PFV thing AG 3SG to certain:RED PVP AG 1PL.INCL PRF happy CONT | \glt ‘What things did she do so that we (the readers of the story) know that she was happy?’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\ref{sec:11.5.3}.2} Ki also marks \textsc{temporal} clauses\is{Clause!temporal}.\footnote{\label{fn:525}The double function of reflexes of PPN *kia as both optative/purposive and temporal markers is also found with \ili{Māori} kia (\citealt[62, 459]{Bauer1993}) and \ili{Tahitian} \textit{{\ꞌ}ia} (\citealt[138–139]{LazardPeltzer2000}); unlike Rapa Nui, in these languages the particle is not used in temporal clauses referring to the past. In Rapa Nui, the purposive sense of *kia has to a large degree been taken over by mo, as discussed above.} As the examples below show, these occur in various contexts: with past\is{Past} reference, with future\is{Future} reference, or habitual\is{Aspect!habitual}. Ki{}-clauses usually occur before the main clause, but as \REF{ex:11.195} shows, they may also be placed after the main clause.
Content 1: \gll He aŋa tātou he haka hōrou mo turu o tātou ki tai \textbf{ki} tu\ꞌu mai a nua. | \gls NTR work 1PL.INCL NTR CAUS quick for go_down of 1PL.INCL to sea when arrive hither PROP Mum | \glt ‘We will work quickly, so we can go to the sea when Mum comes.’

Knowledge Point: The preposition ki has the same use, see \REF{ex:4.266} on p.~\pageref{ex:4.266}. This shows that the two particles ki, though etymologically distinct, are closely related.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌO ira e ko hakarē a au i a koe \textbf{ki} tō\ꞌoku hope\ꞌara\ꞌa. | \gls because_of ANA IPFV NEG.IPFV leave PROP 1SG ACC ART 2SG to POSS.1SG.O end | \glt ‘Therefore I will not leave you till the end of my days.’

Knowledge Point: \textit{{\ꞌ}O}{}-marked clauses usually occur after the main clause and are always verb-initial. The subject is expressed in the same way as in main clauses: unmarked as in \REF{ex:11.200}, or with the agent marker e as in \REF{ex:11.201}.
Content 1: \gll He oho a Eva he piko \textbf{\ꞌo} kī rō a koro mo ta\ꞌe oho ki hiva. | \gls NTR go PROP Eva NTR hide lest say EMPH PROP Dad for CONNEG go to mainland | \glt ‘Eva went and hid lest Dad would tell her not to go to the mainland.’
Content 2: \gll He tētere he pipiko tahi \textbf{\ꞌo} vara\ꞌa rō e te Miru i a rāua mo tiaŋi. | \gls NTR PL:run NTR PL:hide all lest catch EMPH AG ART Miru ACC PROP 3PL for kill | \glt ‘All of them fled and hid, lest the Miru would catch them to kill them.’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui, a verb marked with \textit{{\ꞌ}o} is usually followed by the asseverative particle rō\is{ro (emphatic marker)@rō (emphatic marker)} (\sectref{sec:7.4.2}), as illustrated in (\ref{ex:11.200}–\ref{ex:11.201}) above.
Content 1: \gll He oho a Eva he piko \textbf{\ꞌo} kī rō a koro mo ta\ꞌe oho ki hiva. | \gls NTR go PROP Eva NTR hide lest say EMPH PROP Dad for CONNEG go to mainland | \glt ‘Eva went and hid lest Dad would tell her not to go to the mainland.’
Content 2: \gll He tētere he pipiko tahi \textbf{\ꞌo} vara\ꞌa rō e te Miru i a rāua mo tiaŋi. | \gls NTR PL:run NTR PL:hide all lest catch EMPH AG ART Miru ACC PROP 3PL for kill | \glt ‘All of them fled and hid, lest the Miru would catch them to kill them.’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally \textit{{\ꞌ}o} is found in complement clauses expressing a negative complement: \textit{\mbox{ri{\ꞌ}ari{\ꞌ}a} {\ꞌ}o} ‘to fear lest’, \textit{haŋa {\ꞌ}o} ‘to want that not...’ \is{o ‘lest’@{\ꞌ}o ‘lest’|)}(see (\ref{ex:11.75}–\ref{ex:11.76}) in \sectref{sec:11.3.5}).
Content 1: \gll \ꞌAi a Vai Ora ka ri\ꞌari\ꞌa nō \ob\textbf{\ꞌo} māuiui rō \ꞌi te rari\,\cb. | \gls then PROP Vai Ora CNTG afraid just {\db}lest sick EMPH at ART wet | \glt ‘Then Vai Ora was afraid (her child) would get ill from being wet.’
Content 2: \gll Ana haŋa koe \ob\textbf{\ꞌo} mana\ꞌu rahi koe ki te poki\,\cb, mo tāua \ꞌana e hāpa\ꞌo i a rāua ko Kava. | \gls IRR want 2SG {\db}lest think much 2SG to ART child for 1DU.INCL IDENT IPFV care_for ACC PROP 3PL PROM Kava | \glt ‘If you don’t want to worry (lit. if you want lest you think much) about the boy, we will care for him and Kava.’

Knowledge Point: Type 3 clauses are subordinate, even though they lack a conjunction or subordinating marker; this is indicated by the fact that they are negated with the constituent negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e} (\sectref{sec:10.5.6}.5), not by a main clause negator. Here is an example of a negated temporal clause. Cf. also \REF{ex:11.257} on p.~\pageref{ex:11.257} (a reason clause marked with he).
Content 1: \gll Te nu\ꞌu nei i tētere ai \textbf{he} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} ha\ꞌati\ꞌa e te hua\ꞌai mo hāipoipo ararua. | \gls ART people PROX PFV PL:run PVP NTR/PRED CONNEG permit AG ART family for marry the_two | \glt ‘These people fled because their family did not allow them to marry.’

Knowledge Point: Cohesive clauses marked with imperfective e\is{e (imperfective)} indicate events simultaneous to the event in the main clause. They may be continuous\is{Aspect!continuous} as in \REF{ex:11.213} or habitual\is{Aspect!habitual} as in \REF{ex:11.214}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{ha\ꞌuru} \textbf{nō} \textbf{\ꞌā} a Eva he hakaroŋo atu ko te re\ꞌo ka raŋi... | \gls IPFV sleep just CONT PROP Eva NTR listen away PROM ART voice CNTG call | \glt ‘When Eva was still asleep, she heard a voice calling...’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{kā} \textbf{era} i tou \ꞌumu era paurō te mahana, \ꞌina he \ꞌō\ꞌotu te \ꞌumu e pō rō era. | \gls IPFV kindle DIST ACC DEM earth_oven DIST every ART day NEG PRED cooked ART earth_oven IPFV night EMPH DIST | \glt ‘When they lighted the earth oven every day, the food was not cooked until night.’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{Imperfective e} Temporal clauses may also be marked with imperfective e\is{e (imperfective)}. These clauses express a continuous event \is{Simultaneity}simultaneous to the one in the main clause. As discussed in \sectref{sec:7.2.5.4}, e-marked verbs in main clauses are followed either by a postverbal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} (PVD) or the continuity marker \textit{{\ꞌ}ā/{\ꞌ}ana}. The same is true in temporal clauses\is{Clause!temporal}: the verb is either followed by a PVD\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} \is{e (imperfective)!e V PVD}as in (\ref{ex:11.224}–\ref{ex:11.225}), or by \textit{{\ꞌ}ā/{\ꞌ}ana}\is{e (imperfective)!e V {\ꞌ}ā} as in (\ref{ex:11.226}–\ref{ex:11.227}).
Content 1: \gll He me\ꞌe mai mai roto mai tau \ꞌana era \textbf{e} \textbf{vero} \textbf{atu} \textbf{era} hai akaue... | \gls NTR thing hither from inside from DEM cave DIST IPFV throw away DIST INS stake | \glt ‘They said from inside the cave, while (the enemy) threw sticks at them...’
Content 2: \gll He oho haka\ꞌou \textbf{e} \textbf{\ꞌui} \textbf{era} ki te hare, ki te hare era. | \gls NTR go again IPFV ask DIST to ART house to ART house DIST | \glt ‘He went again, asking from house to house.’
Content 3: \gll Ko tu\ꞌu haka\ꞌou mai \ꞌā tū ŋā poki era \textbf{e} \textbf{ma\ꞌu} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā} i te ra\ꞌakau. | \gls PRF arrive again hither CONT DEM PL child DIST IPFV carry EMPH CONT ACC ART castor_oil_plant | \glt ‘The children had come back, carrying castor oil leaves.’
Content 4: \gll Terā ka pāhono mai e Vaha \textbf{e} \textbf{koa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā}... | \gls then CNTG answer hither AG Vaha IPFV happy EMPH CONT | \glt ‘Then Vaha answered happily...’

Knowledge Point: With \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}, the subject is always the same as in the main clause; in the PVD\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} construction, the subject can be different, as in \REF{ex:11.224}.
Content 1: \gll He me\ꞌe mai mai roto mai tau \ꞌana era \textbf{e} \textbf{vero} \textbf{atu} \textbf{era} hai akaue... | \gls NTR thing hither from inside from DEM cave DIST IPFV throw away DIST INS stake | \glt ‘They said from inside the cave, while (the enemy) threw sticks at them...’

Knowledge Point: With \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}, the predicate can be an adjective, as in \REF{ex:11.227}; in the PVD\is{Demonstrative!postverbal} construction, this is rare, unless the adjective indicates a process. (The same is true in main clauses, \sectref{sec:7.2.5.4}).
Content 1: \gll Terā ka pāhono mai e Vaha \textbf{e} \textbf{koa} \textbf{rō} \textbf{\ꞌā}... | \gls then CNTG answer hither AG Vaha IPFV happy EMPH CONT | \glt ‘Then Vaha answered happily...’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the subordinate clause may precede or follow the main clause. As in \REF{ex:11.229}, the verb is often followed by a postverbal demonstrative\is{Demonstrative!postverbal}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ka} \textbf{turu} \textbf{nei} tāua, he tu\ꞌu mai a koro era ko Vaha ki nei. | \gls CNTG go_down PROX 1DU.INCL NTR arrive hither PROP Dad DIST PROM Vaha to PROX | \glt ‘When we go down, father Vaha will come here.’

Knowledge Point: Temporal adjuncts can be expressed by a temporal noun preceded by a preposition; the most general temporal noun is hora ‘time’. The adjunct can be further specified by a modifier, e.g. a genitive as in \REF{ex:11.230} or a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} as in \REF{ex:11.231}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{\ꞌI} \textbf{te} \textbf{hora} \textbf{era} \ꞌana o tō\ꞌoku māmārū\ꞌau era i oti rō ai rā oho iŋa. | \gls at ART time DIST IDENT of POSS.1SG.O grandmother DIST PFV finish EMPH PVP DIST go NMLZ | \glt ‘In my grandmother’s time this custom (lit. going) finished.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{\ꞌI} \textbf{te} \textbf{hora} \textbf{era} e ora nō \ꞌā tā\ꞌana kenu era, \ꞌā\ꞌana te oho ki te kona aŋa... | \gls at ART time DIST IPFV live just CONT POSS.3SG.A husband DIST POSS.3SG.A ART go to ART place work | \glt ‘At the time when her husband was still alive, she was the one who would go to work...’

Knowledge Point: In the constructions above, hora ena/era resembles a temporal conjunction\is{Conjunction}; semantic bleaching is taking place, where hora ena/era comes to mean little more than ‘when’. Notice however, that the construction is syntactically still a nominal phrase with relative clause\is{Clause!relative}: as \REF{ex:11.233} shows, the aspectual can be omitted, something which is only possible in relative clauses\is{Clause!relative} (\sectref{sec:11.4.5}). (Also, the verb \textit{take{\ꞌ}a} has been raised from the relative clause\is{Clause!relative}.)
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Hora} take\ꞌa \textbf{era} e au, ¡\ꞌai te nehenehe! | \gls time see DIST AG 1SG ~there ART beautiful | \glt ‘When I saw her, she was so beautiful!’

Knowledge Point: \subparagraph{\textit{{\ꞌ}Ō ira}}\is{o ira ‘before’@{\ꞌ}ō ira ‘before’} \textit{{\ꞌ}ō ira} ‘before’\footnote{\label{fn:531}Not to be confused with \textit{{\ꞌ}o ira} ‘therefore’ (\sectref{sec:11.6.4}).} consists of the otherwise unknown particle \textit{{\ꞌ}ō}, followed by the pro-form ira (\sectref{sec:4.6.5.2}). It is always followed by a ka{}-marked verb. As \REF{ex:11.236} shows, the subject after \textit{{\ꞌ}ō ira} is usually preverbal.
Content 1: \gll Te rāua henua ra\ꞌe i noho ko Perú, \textbf{\ꞌō_ira} te Inca ka tu\ꞌu. | \gls ART 3PL land first PFV stay PROM Peru before ART Inca CNTG arrive | \glt ‘The first land where they lived was Peru, before the Incas arrived.’

Knowledge Point: In the examples above, the subject of the main clause reaches a certain state or end point; for example, in \REF{ex:11.238}, Te Manu reaches a state of satiation after having eaten. The stative verb in the ka V rō\is{ka (aspect marker)!ka V rō} clause may also specify the action of the main clause, which is performed – or is to be performed – to a certain extent or in a certain way. (Cf. the use of ka before numerals to mark an extent, \sectref{sec:4.3.2.2}).
Content 1: \gll I noho ai a Te Manu \ꞌi muri tū pāpārū\ꞌau era \textbf{ka} \textbf{rova\ꞌa} \textbf{rō} ho\ꞌe \ꞌahuru tūma\ꞌa matahiti. | \gls PFV stay PVP PROP Te Manu at near DEM grandfather DIST CNTG obtain EMPH one ten more_or_less year | \glt ‘Te Manu stayed with his grandfather until he was about ten years old.’

Knowledge Point: A second way to express ‘until’ is by means of \textit{{\ꞌ}ātā}\is{ata ‘until’@{\ꞌ}ātā ‘until’} ({\textless} Sp. hasta). \textit{{\ꞌ}Ātā} is used in nominal constructions before the preposition ki (see \REF{ex:4.267} on p.~\pageref{ex:4.267}), but also in verbal constructions, followed by ka V rō\is{ka (aspect marker)!ka V rō}. As \REF{ex:11.242} shows, \textit{{\ꞌ}ātā} may be shortened to \textit{{\ꞌ}ā}:
Content 1: \gll Mai rā hora \textbf{\ꞌātā} \textbf{ki} te hora nei kai e\ꞌa haka\ꞌou e tahi Rapa Nui. | \gls from DIST time until to ART time PROX NEG.PFV go_out again NUM one Rapa Nui | \glt ‘From that time until now, not one Rapa Nui left (the island) anymore.’
Content 2: \gll ...\ꞌai ka haka teka ka oho ki Haŋa Piko \textbf{\ꞌā} tāua \textbf{ka} tomo \textbf{rō} nei. | \gls ~~~~there CNTG CAUS turn CNTG go to Hanga Piko until 1DU.INCL CNTG go_ashore EMPH PROX | \glt ‘...then we will turn and go to Hanga Piko, until we come ashore.’

Knowledge Point: In these examples, the main verb is a motion verb\is{Verb!motion}; the ki{}-marked noun phrase is the Goal of movement. This noun phrase is followed by a bare verb, of which the preceding noun is the Patient.\footnote{\label{fn:533}\citet[424]{Clark1983Review} points out that the same construction occurs in \ili{Marquesan} and \ili{Mangarevan}. Different from what Clark suggests, in Rapa Nui this construction is not limited to generic objects, as \REF{ex:11.247} shows.}
Content 1: \gll He iri ararua \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{rāua} \textbf{hoi} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌaru} \textbf{mai}. | \gls NTR ascend the_two to ART 3PL horse grab hither | \glt ‘Both of them went to grab their horse.’

Knowledge Point: The noun in this construction is not an incorporated object\is{Object!incorporation} of the following verb: it is the head of a regular noun phrase, marked with the article te and preceded by a preposition. A somewhat more plausible analysis would be to consider the verb as incorporated into the noun; however, the directional\is{Directional} mai in \REF{ex:11.247} shows that the verb is the head of a true verb phrase. It is best to analyse these constructions simply as a combination of a noun phrase and a bare purpose clause, rather than assuming that the noun phrase + verb are a single constituent. An additional reason to do so is that this construction is not an isolated phenomenon, but an instance (admittedly, the most common instance) of a group of constructions in which a locative noun phrase and a purpose clause occur together. Related constructions include:
Content 1: \gll He iri ararua \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{rāua} \textbf{hoi} \textbf{\ꞌa\ꞌaru} \textbf{mai}. | \gls NTR ascend the_two to ART 3PL horse grab hither | \glt ‘Both of them went to grab their horse.’

Knowledge Point: These examples suggest that ki te N V in (\ref{ex:11.246}–\ref{ex:11.248}) should not be analysed as a special construction involving a single NP+V constituent. Rather, it is a combination of two constituents, a nominal Goal phrase followed by a bare purpose clause, either of which may also occur on its own.
Content 1: \gll Te poki nei i iri atu ai \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{tarake} \textbf{toke}. | \gls ART child PROX PFV ascend away PVP to ART corn steal | \glt ‘This boy went (to the field) to steal corn.’
Content 2: \gll He turu tahi mātou \textbf{ki} \textbf{te} \textbf{pērīkura} \textbf{māta\ꞌita\ꞌi} \ꞌi te hare hāpī era. | \gls NTR go_down all 1PL.EXCL to ART movie watch at ART house learn DIST | \glt ‘We all went down to watch a movie at school.’

Knowledge Point: In these constructions, he can also be considered as a nominal predicate marker followed by a nominalised verb (hence the double gloss in the examples above)\is{Verb!nominalised}. One reason to do so, is that other nominal constructions are also used to express reasons: in \REF{ex:11.258} a nominalised verb\is{Verb!nominalised} preceded by a possessive pronoun, in \REF{ex:11.259} a subordinate existential construction (an existential main clause would be \textit{{\ꞌ}Ina he me{\ꞌ}e mo kai}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Tu\ꞌu} \textbf{ta\ꞌe} \textbf{hakaroŋo} ena ki te vānaŋa o te taote; \ꞌo ira koe i māuiui haka\ꞌou ena. | \gls POSS.2SG.O CONNEG listen MED to ART word of ART doctor because_of ANA 2SG PFV sick again MED | \glt ‘You didn’t listen to the words of the doctor, therefore you got sick again.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{kore} mo kai, \ꞌo ira au e taŋi nei. | \gls PRED thing lack for eat because_of ANA 1SG IPFV cry PROX | \glt ‘There is nothing (lit. the lack of things) to eat, therefore I am crying.’

Knowledge Point: \is{Clause!result|(}Results may be marked by the adverbial connector \textit{{\ꞌ}o}\is{o ‘because of’@{\ꞌ}o ‘because of’} ira\is{ira (anaphor)} ‘because of that; therefore’ (the reason preposition \textit{{\ꞌ}o} followed by the pro-form ira). As \REF{ex:11.261} shows, it is possible to mark both the reason clause (in this case, a nominal construction) and the result clause.
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI te ta\ꞌe hakaroŋo ō\ꞌou \textbf{\ꞌo} \textbf{ira} koe i hiŋa ena. | \gls at ART CONNEG listen POSS.2SG.O because_of ANA 2SG PFV fall MED | \glt ‘Because you didn’t listen, therefore you fell.’

Knowledge Point: The aspectual marker\is{Aspect marker} ka\is{ka (aspect marker)}, in combination with the directional atu\is{atu ‘away’}, can be used in a concessive sense, indicating a circumstance which might be expected to prevent – but actually does not prevent – the event in the main clause.\footnote{\label{fn:535}This does not mean that all ka V atu constructions have a concessive sense, see e.g. example \REF{ex:11.263} above.}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ka} \textbf{hāŋai} \textbf{atu} \textbf{ena} ki a koe, he mate koe. | \gls CNTG feed away MED to PROP 2SG NTR die 2SG | \glt ‘If (the two spirits) feed you, you will die.’

Knowledge Point: Alternatively, mā\is{ma ‘with’@mā ‘with’} ‘and, with’ may be used, followed by a nominalised verb.\footnote{\label{fn:538}Mā has a limited distribution in Rapa Nui: it is only used in the construction under discussion and in numerals. Both uses are also found in (and were probably borrowed from) \ili{Tahitian} (see Footnote \ref{fn:167} on p.~\pageref{fn:167}).}\is{Verb!nominalised} As \REF{ex:11.273} shows, mā te may be assimilated to mata.
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌa\ꞌamu, \textbf{mata} ta\ꞌe \ꞌite hia pē nei ē: he tahutahu. | \gls NTR tell with_the CONNEG know yet like PROX thus NTR witch | \glt ‘She told (the other woman), without knowing that she was a witch.’

Knowledge Point: Notice that e V era\is{e (imperfective)!e V PVD} is obligatory when the circumstantial \textit{ko V {\ꞌ}ā}\is{ko V {\ꞌ}ā (perfect aspect)} clause comes first; when the circumstantial clause follows the main clause, the main clause may be he{}-marked, as in (\ref{ex:11.274}–\ref{ex:11.275}) above.
Content 1: \gll He taŋi \textbf{ko} \textbf{\ꞌū} \textbf{\ꞌā} era pē he pua\ꞌa. | \gls NTR cry PRF bellow CONT DIST like PRED cow | \glt ‘He cried, howling like a cow.’
Content 2: \gll He raŋi mai \textbf{ko} \textbf{riri} \textbf{rivariva} \textbf{\ꞌā}... | \gls NTR call hither PRF angry good:RED CONT | \glt ‘Very angry, she shouted...’
